conclusion: Analyze the geometry and refraction involved to determine the increase in the range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light hole after embedding the glass brick.
Calculate the initial angle of incidence without the glass brick using the tangent function.
Given diameter L = 40 cm and thickness d = 20√3 cm.
The light travels a horizontal distance of L/2 = 20 cm. Calculate θ1 using tan(θ1) = 1/√3, resulting in θ1 = 30°.
Calculate the angle of incidence with the glass brick using Snell's Law.
Refractive index of the glass is √3.
Using Snell's Law, calculate θ2 = sin⁻¹(√3/6) ≈ 16.1°.
Determine the increase in the range of light incidence: Increase = 30° - 16.1° = 13.9°.
Account for the symmetric nature of the problem: Total increase = 2 × 13.9° = 27.8°.
The range of light incident on the central point at the bottom of the light hole is increased by approximately 28° compared to before embedding the glass brick.
